newsitem.title: USA: Kmart, other US high-yield debt firm before supply.
newsitem.headline: Kmart, other US high-yield debt firm before supply.

text.p: Kmart bonds remained firm on takeover talk at midday, traders said, with other U.S. corporate high-yield prices stable with a firm bias despite prospects for $2.5 billion in issuance before Thanksgiving.
Investment-grade trade, meanwhile, was also subordinated to a bustling primary market as issuers prepared to capitalize on long-Treasury yields well below 6-1/2 percent.

Topping junk trade, Kmart Corp debt was mostly quiet but firm at midday following rumors on Tuesday that the retailer is a target for buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis and Roberts & Co. Some longer debt was quoted higher, however, one trader said.
Kmart's 7.95s of 2023 were bid at 77 compared with an earlier quoted of 76-5/8 bid, 77-1/2 offer.
Both Kmart and KKR had declined comment on the rumor.
Traders said higher third quarter earnings reported on Wednesday failed to spark much activity for the debt. Kmart reported Q3 revenues of $7.847 billion and a 0.1 percent rise in same store sales.

Elsewhere, Trump-related debt dipped amid heightened uncertainty surrounding an expected investment in Trump's Castle in Atlantic City, traders said. Trump Castle debt was down about one point to 92-1/2, said one trader.
Otherwise, by all accounts, new issue talk surrounding the host of high-yield issues set to price took precedence, traders said. Buyers can absorb the paper, one trader said.

"If the market didn't think (buyers) could take the supply you'd see the secondary trade off a lot and you haven't seen that," the trader said. "Remember that this is pretty much it before the end of the year, too."
High-yield issues priced so far on Wednesday include:
-- $150 million 10-year Baa3/BBB 10-year 144a notes from Aristech Chemicals Corp priced as 6-7/8s to yield 80 basis points over the Treasury curve.
